docs.lead_paragraph: Faced with natural disaster and political crises, the last week of President Obama's first year in office has hardly been a breather. This weekend he places himself at the center of the response to the earthquake in Haiti and the Massachusetts Senate race.
docs.abstract: On Haiti, health care and the Massachusetts Senate race.
docs.snippet: On Haiti, health care and the Massachusetts Senate race.

docs.lead_paragraph: An excise tax on high-cost insurance plans is the most significant measure to slow the relentless rise in health care spending.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ben Nelson, below, Democrat of Nebraska, on Friday asked the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, to remove a special provision in the health care legislation that would have the federal government pay all the costs for a proposed expansion of Medicaid in Nebraska. The provision was added to the Senate version of the legislation to help secure Mr. Nelson's vote after he expressed concerns about the cost of the expansion. Under the Senate bill, the federal government would pick up the full cost of the expansion for three years, after which states would have to pay a small portion of the expense.
docs.abstract: Sen Ben Nelson asks Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to remove special provision in health care legislation that would have federal government pay costs for proposed expansion of Medicaid in Nebraska; provision was added to Senate version of legislation to help secure Nelson's vote after he expressed concerns about cost of expansion, but it sparked torrent of criticism; Nelson photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical industry's trade group will oppose health care legislation if the White House and Congress reduce a proposed 12-year exclusivity period for biologic drugs, according to an e-mail message that the head of the trade group, Billy Tauzin, sent to the group's board members on Friday. The board includes the chief executives of Pfizer, Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb and other leading pharmaceutical companies.
docs.abstract: Billy Tauzin, head of Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, says that trade group would oppose health care legislation if White House and Congress reduced proposed 12-year exclusivity period for biologic drugs, which are made inside living cells (M)
docs.snippet: The pharmaceutical industry's trade group will oppose health care legislation if the White House and Congress reduce a proposed 12-year exclusivity period for biologic drugs, according to an e-mail message that the head of the trade group, Billy...

docs.lead_paragraph: White House and Congressional leaders working on a final version of far-reaching health care legislation have wrapped up their discussions - at least for the weekend - and officials will now wait for cost analysis on various proposals to bridge the final differences between the House and Senate version so of the bill.
docs.abstract: White House aides and Congressional leaders ended their negotiations and now await additional cost analysis from the Congressional Budget Office.
docs.snippet: White House aides and Congressional leaders ended their negotiations and now await additional cost analysis from the Congressional Budget Office.

docs.lead_paragraph: Can a regimen of exercise, vitamins, supplements and hormone shots slow down nature's clock? That's the question explored in The New York Times Magazine this week. The story begins with 51-year-old John Bellizzi of Rye, N.Y., a patient of Dr. Florence Comite, a Manhattan endocrinologist.

headline.main: Testosterone to Fine-Tune an Aging Body

docs.abstract: Can a regimen of exercise, vitamins, supplements and hormone shots slow down nature's clock?
docs.snippet: Can a regimen of exercise, vitamins, supplements and hormone shots slow down nature's clock?
